content.description: Starts at the sea cave and moves up the semi-okay looking constriction/corner.
content.location: On a separate formation. North on the beach from the Kachemak Crack group. Can be set up as a TR from the Kcrack approach trail or by scrambling the loose rock to the left of the climb.,

content.description: Nice blocky dihedral to the right of the unknown dihedral.  Nice face moves and a short crux section.  Interesting and exposed finish.
content.protection: Bolts and some gear to 1" would be much appreciated.  2 bolt chain anchor.
content.location: This is the far right climb.  There is a smooth almost featureless wall and Salt Dawg is in the dihedral on the right.

content.description: Starts to the right of the start of the gear protected Kachemak Crack climb, clip a bolt off the deck, place some gear in the horizontal crack above, figure out how to get to the next two bolts and then place more gear on your way to the chains.
content.protection: Three bolts and some cams or nuts.  A BD #1 works in the left side of the horizontal or a BD .3 or .4 in the right side of the horizontal crack.  Above the third bolt you can fish in nuts or cams and the climbing eases to the chains.
content.location: This climb is just to the right of Kachemak Crack.

content.description: Nice climb, crux is right off the deck.
content.protection: Single rack to 1", protect the horizontals, as well as the diagonal crack that runs throughout some of the climb.  Two bolt chain anchor.
content.location: This climb is located on a nice slab of rock and is the far left climb in the area.

content.description: Start and belay from same ledge as Bill's Dihedral, trending the into leftmost dihedral. If you finesse your way through the initial schmegma, you'll be rewarded with some fantastic stemming on good rock until the finish!
content.protection: small rack...C3's; .3-.5; draws - 2 bolt anchor w/ chains

content.description: Start by practicing your gymnastics through the lower schmegma until you find excellent but hard stemming on solid edges and good rock. Gain the rest corner and get stoked on the exposed move out. Keep your shit together through the upper face and enjoy the landscaping.
content.protection: Single rack to 3" (C3's are nice), 7 bolts, 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Begin in the obvious dihedral left of Salty Dawg.

content.description: Finger crack dihedral, crux is low-mid on the route.  Two or three mantle moves are tricky but the highlights are a beautiful finger crack in the dihedral and stiff liebacking moves to pull the roof above.
content.protection: Bolts and gear.  The climb could use more bolts in a couple key places.  Gear to one inch
content.location: This climb is to the right of the Kachemak Crack area and is located in a dihedral with a roof near the top.  You can access the chains by hiking the trail in between it and Kachemak Crack and heading up and around.

content.description:
Sun from about noon till sunset.  Whole bunch of weird signs now litter the area, but aside from the occasional campers and the kids from the local climbing group it's a pretty secluded and peaceful place.   

  This crag has seen a mix of development both good and bad over the last few years, many bolts exist on routes, some appear to be unfinished projects, others are partially bolted routes that are generally done on TR.
